title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16
author: Various
snippet: In one of my fishing excursions, a few years since, I becameaccidentally acquainted with a worthy farmer of the name of Thompson,who lived on the banks of the Esk, in the neighbourhood of thebeautifully-situated town of Langholm.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In the soil which covers these fields, particles of gold have occasionally been found ; copper ore is found at Blair Logic, Airthrie, and at Fetlar, in Orkney ; antimony at Langholm ; manganese in the neighbourhood of Aberdeen ; silver has been wrought at Alva in Stirlingshire, in Clackmannanshire,  and at Leadhills in Lanarkshire ; there are extensive slate-quarries in Aberdeenshire, Argyleshire, Perthshire, and Peebles-shire ; marble is found in Argyleshire, Sutherland, and the Hebrides ; sandstone abounds generally throughout the country ; and granite and other primitive rocks within the limits of the Grampians.

title: Diary of the late Rajah of Kolhapoor, during his visit to Europe in 1870.
author: Rajah Ram Chuttraputtee
snippet: Mr. M met us atthe distance of twenty miles from Langholm.

title: Diary of the late Rajah of Kolhapoor, during his visit to Europe in 1870.
author: Rajah Ram Chuttraputtee
snippet: Arrived at Langholm about8.30 P.M.

title: Diary of the late Rajah of Kolhapoor, during his visit to Europe in 1870.
author: Rajah Ram Chuttraputtee
snippet: Took a drive through the Park and returned home about 6.80 P.M.Wth.—Went to Euston Square Station, and left at 10.30 A.M.for Langholm.

title: Rambles in Europe:
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison
snippet: At Stubholm, near Langholm, was born the great wit of the clan, Archie Armstrong.

title: Rambles in Europe:
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison
snippet: This clan had many places of strength in these parts, such as Sark, Kinmont, Hollgreen, Hollis, Mumbyhirst, the castle of Harelaw, Irving castle near Langholm, Whitehaugh, Mangerton, Pud- dington, Hilles, and others; yet Gilnockie hall, or the home at the Hollows just described, was the strongest of all.

title: Rambles in Europe:
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison
snippet: I arrived at Langholm in the evening, which is situated, with its 3,000 inhabitants, among the high hills or mountains, — very lovely for situation, — a quiet retreat from the bustle of the outside world.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: At Langholm he once saw a heap of smuggled tobacco publicly burned.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: the evening at Langholm, where the village is situated at the confluence of the two streams

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: The slope from this to Langholm is just eleven miles, arid the road excellent ; the country was exceedingly picturesque, though then without trees, and full of sheep, which, as the young Duke of Buccleuch and his Duchess were daily expected, had been taught to line the road daily through which they were to pass, that they might see wherein the riches of the land consisted.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: Advancing onwards, the banks become more rugged and romantic, and luxuriate in natural timberof great beauty around Gilnockie Tower, theruined residence of Johnnie Armstrong, so renowned in Border story ; beyond which the samesylvan features continue along the banks of theEsk to Langholm, the chief town in Eskdale, embosomed in wood, and environed by hills, presenting scenery of that quiet unobtrusive characterwhich sooths rather than overpowers.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Accordingly, having reached Ecclefechan on their way to Dumfries, the Englishcounsels prevailed, and the insurgents halted at the former village, turned south,and directed their march on Langholm, with the design of making for the west ofEngland.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Jacobite gentlemen, therefore, retreated to Moffat, and thence to Langholm and Hawick.

author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But an event of greater importance, was the fate ofJohn Armstrong of Gilnockie, near Langholm.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: " Why not go up the Esk ?—there's a path whichtakes over the hills just above Langholm.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: This Cranstoun hath controlof your castles of Caerlaverock, Langholm, andLochmaben, and draweth your rents in the King'sname.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: He hath been licking his chops these twelvemonths past over my barony of Langholm.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: The confiscation of Lord MaxAvell's castles of Caerlaverock, Lochmaben, and Langholm was enough to convince themost ignorant that Cranstoun was my Lord's mostdangerous enemy; and the continued contumacy anddefiance exhibited by the latter to the Scottish Councilfurnished a standing provocation to interfere with hispossessions.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: The Hollows, the tower of Johnny Armstrong,better known as Gilnockie, is an oblong buildingperched on a bank overlooking the Esk somewherebetween Canonby and Langholm.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: " Langholm belongs to my Lord Maxwell."

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: But ye say yourfortune is slender—what say ye to the barony ofLangholm ?"
